content.subtitle: If you have ever called add(), addAll(), map(), or toList() to build a list or map, you might want to check out collection if, collection…

paragraphs.name: 9c2d
paragraphs.text: Exploring collections in Dart

paragraphs.name: c6be
paragraphs.text: If you have ever called add(), addAll(), map(), or toList() to build a list or map, you might want to check out collection if, collection for, and spreads. Last year, Dart added these features in version 2.3.
In this article, we’ll look at collections, explore these new features, and see some interesting examples. By mastering these features, you can make your code more succinct and easier to read.

paragraphs.name: d783
paragraphs.text: Collections

paragraphs.name: d83b
paragraphs.text: First, we need to understand what a collection is. A collection is an object that contains other objects. For example:

paragraphs.name: b213
paragraphs.text: List: an ordered collection of objects with a length (also called an array)

paragraphs.name: 0ec3
paragraphs.text: Set: an unordered collection of unique objects

paragraphs.name: 439f
paragraphs.text: Map: an unordered collection of key-value pairs

paragraphs.name: 6e59
paragraphs.text: Queue: an ordered collection that can add/remove objects on both ends

paragraphs.name: a8dc
paragraphs.text: SplayTreeMap: an ordered collection of key-value pairs based on a self-balancing binary tree

paragraphs.name: b6d5
paragraphs.text: These types are available in the dart:collection package. For even more collection types, check out package:collection on pub.dev.

paragraphs.name: 2c5f
paragraphs.text: Each of these collection types implements Iterable, which provides common behavior like running a function on each object in the collection, getting the first object, determining the length of the collection, and more.

paragraphs.name: 8a10
paragraphs.text: Collection literals

paragraphs.name: 62ea
paragraphs.text: Dart supports syntax for constructing three types of collections: list literals ([]), map literals ({}) and set literals (also {}).

paragraphs.name: 66a2
paragraphs.text: Here’s a list literal:

paragraphs.name: 10f1
paragraphs.text: Here’s a map literal:
And here’s a set literal, added in Dart 2.3:

paragraphs.name: e4ce
6ea9
paragraphs.text: If you’re wondering why maps and sets can use the same {} syntax, it’s because Dart uses type inference to differentiate. The type system determines the type based on the type of parameters a and b. It can usually determine this based on the contents—for example, {1} is obviously a Set, and {1: 2} is obviously a Map.

paragraphs.name: 11b4
paragraphs.text: Note: Using {} constructs a map by default. To create a set, you can use a generic type annotation: <String>{}. Using two generic type parameters creates a map: <String, String>{}.

paragraphs.name: 3a10
paragraphs.text: Types of elements
Each item in a collection literal is usually a value or an expression, but can also be one of these new features: a collection if, collection for, or spread. All of these are called elements.

paragraphs.name: be34
paragraphs.text: Each element unpacks zero or more items and puts them in the surrounding collection. For example, a string literal (say, "oatmeal") results in one item, but a collection for unpacks 0 or more items. These features can also be combined in interesting ways, as we’ll explore below.

paragraphs.name: 2c34
paragraphs.text: Spreads

paragraphs.name: 9d2c
paragraphs.text: A spread takes a collection (for example, a list) and puts its contents into the surrounding collection:

paragraphs.name: 5b55
ce31
paragraphs.text: The preceding code is equivalent to this:

paragraphs.name: ba2f
d9a1
paragraphs.text: You can also use spreads in map and set literals:

paragraphs.name: d56a
fa59
ec0b
paragraphs.text: In both maps and sets, the contents of b overwrite the contents in a when there’s a conflict. For example, calling combineMaps({'foo': 'bar'}, {'foo': 'baz'}) results in a map containing {'foo': 'baz'}.

paragraphs.name: c175
paragraphs.text: Null-aware spreads (…?)

paragraphs.name: af1b
paragraphs.text: A null-aware spread adds the contents to the collection only if the expression after the operator is non-null:

paragraphs.name: ad4a
18fe
747c
paragraphs.text: Collection if
Use the if, else, and else if keywords to add something to a collection based on a condition. Here’s an example of using collection if:

paragraphs.name: 550d
8b10
paragraphs.text: Article(this.title, this.date);

paragraphs.name: 75e7
948a
paragraphs.text: The else keyword can be added on the end:

paragraphs.name: f923
b676
paragraphs.text: Notice where the comma is. The comma can’t be after title because the else is part of the same element. Keeping the if and else together before the comma is what keeps them separate from the next element in the collection.

paragraphs.name: eb4c
paragraphs.text: Adding an else if works too:

paragraphs.name: 94f8
e75f
paragraphs.text: Collection for

paragraphs.name: 830a
paragraphs.text: Lastly, use the for keyword to insert a sequence into the collection:

paragraphs.name: 8fb8
891f
paragraphs.text: Article(this.title, this.date, this.tags);

paragraphs.name: b0cb
47f5
paragraphs.text: In this example, the for expression adds a string for each item in the tags list. Just like a normal for loop in Dart, the tags expression can be any Iterable.

paragraphs.name: e37c
paragraphs.text: Collections in Flutter code

paragraphs.name: c74b
paragraphs.text: If you’re using Dart, there’s a good chance you’re using it to build Flutter apps. Since the features described here were designed with Flutter in mind, let’s take a look at some Flutter code.

paragraphs.name: e1a6
paragraphs.text: Refactoring a build() method

paragraphs.name: 82f5
paragraphs.text: In Flutter, it’s common to build up a list of widgets in a build() method:

paragraphs.name: 4f24
719f
e46b
paragraphs.text: This could be rewritten with a spread:

paragraphs.name: 1a98
paragraphs.text: Widget build(BuildContext context) {

paragraphs.name: e88b
df41
paragraphs.text: Or with a collection for:

paragraphs.name: 7c06
paragraphs.text: The first snippet converts the Article class into a collection of ArticleWidget objects using map(), and then applies the spread operator to expand them into the surrounding list. In the second example, the collection for operator lets you express this a little more succinctly.

paragraphs.name: 1d79
paragraphs.text: A larger build() method

paragraphs.name: 87a1
paragraphs.text: Here’s a more complex example:

paragraphs.name: 4b94
paragraphs.text:
Widget build(BuildContext context) {
  var headerStyle = Theme.of(context).textTheme.headline4;

paragraphs.name: dccb
e6ce
paragraphs.text: The logic to place widgets in the Column is right where a reader might expect, and saves a lot of code. Before these features, the most common way to achieve the same behavior was to create a variable and use normal if statements that call add().
Combining these features

paragraphs.name: e845
paragraphs.text: These features can be combined in interesting ways, as the examples in this section show. Here are a few things to keep in mind:

paragraphs.name: 5ac7
paragraphs.text: Syntactically a collection if, collection for, or spread is a single element — even if it ends up creating multiple objects.

paragraphs.name: 54d0
paragraphs.text: Any expression can go in the body of a collection if or collection for.

paragraphs.name: bd8c
paragraphs.text: Any element can go in the body of a collection if or collection for.

paragraphs.name: bc47
paragraphs.text: Using if and for together

paragraphs.name: 2fbf
paragraphs.text: Here’s some code that creates a list using a collection if inside of a collection for. Here, each article is added to the list if it’s after a certain date:

paragraphs.name: 7c7b
72df
paragraphs.text: If you prefer spreads, the return value could instead be written as ...allArticles.where((article) => article.date.isAfter(ninetyDaysAgo)).

paragraphs.name: 3d0f
paragraphs.text: Using collection if and spreads together

paragraphs.name: f4a9
paragraphs.text: A collection if takes a single element, but if you want to include more than one you can use a spread:

paragraphs.name: 69c6
7ff7
paragraphs.text: Using collection features with async-await

paragraphs.name: 17aa
paragraphs.text: You can also combine asynchronous calls with collection literals. For example, a common pattern is to use Future.wait() to trigger a group of asynchronous calls:

paragraphs.name: 5f89
paragraphs.text: Future<Article> fetchArticle(String id);

paragraphs.name: e1de
8cbd
paragraphs.text: That code can be improved using a collection for:

paragraphs.name: 65e3
a0fa
paragraphs.text: It’s also possible to put an await in a collection literal, although it will wait for each future in sequence:

paragraphs.name: d0b3
28dd
paragraphs.text: The preceding code waits in sequence because it’s equivalent to the following:

paragraphs.name: bcf7
8adf
paragraphs.text: You can also expand a Stream using await for:

paragraphs.name: e0e6
9da6
030f
paragraphs.text: This is another example of how collection if, collection for, and spreads work with other parts of the language. If you’ve used an await for statement, you might be able to guess the behavior: it listens to the stream for new values and puts the body into the surrounding list.
Exploring further

Hopefully these tips help you write cleaner Dart code. There are even more ways to use these features than are mentioned here. If you find a nice technique, share it with the community or mention @dart_lang on Twitter. For more details, check out Making Dart a Better Language for UI or the initial language proposal on GitHub.
